item.content:encoded:
It's still ridiculous sushi this goes far beyond reasonable differentiation. Take yukumi and my current situation of spending over 3M till we finally got it, that's over 333 tries. The probability of not getting a pinchy claw from that(assuming that the drop rate is actually 5%) is 3.8*10^-8, less than one in 25 million, a dubious scenario. Interestingly, if the drop rate is actually .5% all the time and not just when you already have one, that falls to just under 20%, not even a statistically significant outlier. My guess is there was a coding typo some point along the line which causes the check to return that you always have it. Either that or it's 5% per won item, which would still make us outliers(p=.015), but nowhere near the absurdity of a one in 25 million shot occurring twice.

For those curious as to how i got those numbers, you take the probability of failure(.95, then .995, then .9875(.05/4=.0125)) and raise it to the power of the number of attempts. Typically if it drops below .05 it's an outlier, if it drops below 1 in a million it's almost definitely not correct.

This happening once is worse 1 in 25 million odds if 5% is the true probability, .5% is far more likely. As it happened at least twice and the player base is (ridiculously generous estimate in lieu of no data) 100,000, the probability of this occurring twice is 1 in 62,500, and i doubt we are the only ones.

TLDR; The number isn't 5%, it's most likely .5% and the trigger is just wonky, could possibly be 5% chance per won item, but that is unlikely. MATH!

item.content:encoded: Actually it is pretty normal when you're dealing with probability. You have to remember that it is a 5% chance EACH TIME you attempt for the claw. Just because you've lost several games in a row doesn't raise the chances of you actually winning: if you're flipping coins you're just as likely to get H H H H H H H H H H H as you are H T H T H T H T H T H. In the case of a 95:5% rate you're much more likely to lose a hundred times than win. That win within 20 games thing only applies when you theoretically involve an infinite amount of players attempting to obtain it, and the amount of players who have tried it and failed is nowhere close to that. If you arn't OK with that, I suggest just give up on this perm now.
